doc.after: Breeding takes place in shallow freshwater lakes, bays of larger lakes, marshes, and other inland bodies of water, often less than 3Â ha (7.4 acres) in extent and less than 2Â m (6.6Â ft) deep. The red-necked grebe shows a preference for waters in forested areas or, further north, in shrub tundra, and favours sites with abundant emergent vegetation, such as reedbeds.[18] The best breeding habitat is fish-ponds, which have an abundance of food in addition to meeting the other requirements.[19] The American subspecies is less tied to a high aquatic plant density, and sometimes breeds on quite open lakes.[3]
